doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/Nomura/Japan industrial production July 2025 - Sluggish exports to US and China played role in lower output in July Sluggish ex_2025-08-29

processing_metadata.publication: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/Nomura
processing_metadata.input_relative_path: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/Nomura

passages.text: Downside risks to output in Oct- Dec as well as Jul- Sep

Japan's industrial production fell \(1.6\%\) m- m in July 2025 and came in below the market consensus forecast. Output declined for SPE and general passenger vehicles. We attribute this in part to sluggish exports of these items to the US and China. The survey of manufacturers' production forecasts points to a \(1.2\%\) q- q decline in output in Jul- Sep. We note the risk that output in Oct- Dec could also be lower than expected due to carryover effects, as production plans are falling through September.

Japan's industrial production in July 2025 was down \(1.6\%\) m- m, below the Bloomberg median consensus forecast of a \(1.1\%\) decline (Figure 1). Industries that pushed down the headline figure in July included general- purpose, production & business oriented machinery \((- 6.8\%\) m- m, - 1.1ppt contribution to the m- m change) and transport equipment \((- 5.4\%\) , - 0.8ppt). Within the general- purpose, production & business oriented machinery sector, there were negative contributions from SPE \((- 17.6\%\) m- m, - 0.6ppt), while within the transport equipment sector, there were negative contributions from general passenger vehicles \((- 8.3\%\) m- m, - 0.4ppt).
The decline in SPE output is consistent with the \(7.3\%\) m- m decline in real exports of SPE in July (Figure 5). We attribute this in part to sluggish exports to China and South Korea.

We attribute the decline in output of general passenger vehicles to factors such as (1) the imposition of tariffs on automobiles by the Trump administration, and (2) automakers running their production lines below capacity following the 30 July earthquake on the Kamchatka Peninsula in Russia.

The survey of manufacturers' production forecasts as of early August (adjusted by Nomura using average realization and amendment rates) points to a \(0.8\%\) m- m decline in output in August followed by a \(1.1\%\) decline in September. This would work out to a \(1.2\%\) q- q decline in output in Jul- Sep. It now looks more likely that production will fall by more than we had forecast as of 20 August (we forecast a \(0.7\%\) q- q decline).

If actual output through September is in line with production plans, this would mean a carryover effect of around 1.0ppt\\* for Oct- Dec. Thus, even if output were to pick up from September, we note the risk that output could be lower than expected for two straight quarters through Oct- Dec.

\\*Production plans for September indicate a \(1.0\%\) decline versus the Jul- Sep average. As a result, even if the industrial production index were to remain flat from October through December, output in Oct- Dec would decline \(1.0\%\) q- q (ie, there would be a 1.0ppt carryover effect).

The breakdown of production plans for August and September shows negative contributions from general- purpose, production & business oriented machinery \((- 4.1\%)\) q- q, - 0.7ppt q- q contribution) and transport equipment \((- 3.3\%)\) q- q, - 0.5ppt q- q contribution) (Figure 3).
Fig. 1: Industrial production by goods category
Source: Nomura, based on Ministry of Economy, Trade & Industry data
Fig. 2: Shipment-inventory balance
Note: The shipment-inventory balance is the y-y change in shipments minus the y-y change in inventories. Source: Nomura, based on Ministry of Economy, Trade & Industry data
Fig. 3: Contribution to q-q % change by industry and category of goods

Note: (1) Shows contribution \(^{1}\mathbb{G}\) quarterly q-q % change. (2) The darker the shade of green, the bigger the positive contribution in a given quarter, and the darker the shade of red, the bigger the negative \(^{1}\mathbb{G}\) contribution. (3) Only shows industries covered in the survey of manufacturers' production forecasts. The sum of individual industries does not match overall industrial production. (4) Jul-Sep 2025 figures are based on the survey of manufacturers' production forecasts, with adjustments by Nomura for realization and revision ratios. Source: Nomura, based on Ministry of Economy, Trade & Industry data
Fig. 4: Items that pushed down the industrial production index

Note: Here we show the three categories that made the largest negative contributions to July industrial production. Data are shown on a seasonally adjusted basis. Source: Nomura, based on Ministry of Economy, Trade & Industry data
Fig. 5: Real exports of SPE
Note: Adjustments for seasonal factors and inflation are by Nomura. Source: Nomura, based on MOF and BOJ data
